#### Complex Patients

Caring for an ageing population is a critical issue, both now and in the future, as the over-65 population continues to grow. NWL has a high rate of falls, with those in the most deprived groups more likely to experience a fall. However, individuals with learning disabilities face the highest risk—nearly four times greater than average. [Shared Needs Assessment, 2024](https://www.nwlondonicb.nhs.uk/application/files/9617/2805/4039/NW_London_ICS_shared_needs_assessment_2023_to_2024.pdf).

The percentage of deaths in hospital is a metric used to understand where people spend their final days of life. It reflects patterns in end-of-life care, patient choice, and the availability of community or palliative services, with lower hospital death rates often indicating better support for people to die in their preferred setting, such as at home or in hospice care. NWL and London have similar rates of deaths that occur in hospital which is significantly above England. In NWL the 75-84 age group is most likely to the die in hospital. For patients with dementia a lower percentage die in hospital in NWL than the average for NWL, however, compare to the national value for dementia patients dying in hospital it is substantially greater, 39.5% in NWL and 26.3% nationally [OHID, 2023](https://fingertips.phe.org.uk/search/death%20in%20hospital#page/1/gid/1/pat/223/ati/221/are/nE54000027/iid/91894/age/27/sex/4/cat/-1/ctp/-1/yrr/1/cid/4/tbm/1). This suggests care closer to the home is less availble for dementia patients in NWL.

Patients under the mental health act is the most significant outlier for NWL compared to national. Ethnicity is the greatest driver of inequality in this space with the Black ethnic group having the highest rates. Those in the most deprived groups, males and 18-34s are also groups with high rates.


::: callout-tip
##### Patient Insights

-   Some people with SMI experience uncoordinated or disjointed care, with stigma still acting as a barrier to consistent mental health support.
-   Some carers of people with dementia report feeling emotionally unsupported, especially when navigating the health and care system alone.
-   Children with complex needs often face long waits for CAMHS, partly due to assessment delays and limited specialist capacity.
-   Self-managing long-term conditions can cause emotional strain, especially when support feels inconsistent or reactive.
-   Mild anxiety is common in the healthy population, but often goes unrecognized or untreated due to lack of perceived severity.
-   Mental health needs in people with LD are often overlooked, partly due to communication challenges and diagnostic overshadowing.
:::

One way to identify barriers to accessing care is to examine where people use emergency services as a gateway to other services, such as mental health support. Similarly, repeated use of A&E—by high-intensity users (HIUs)—indicates unmet needs in other parts of the health system.

In NWL, there are 500 referrals per 100,000 patients to mental health services via A&E. This figure varies widely, with higher rates among more deprived groups and among Black, Mixed, and White populations. People with severe mental illness (SMI) also experience high referral rates through A&E, highlighting gaps in care for those with known mental health needs. In addition, adults aged 18–64 with learning disabilities show high referral rates, suggesting that they may not be receiving sufficient mental health support.

HIUs represent a small proportion of the population but have particularly high care needs. The most deprived quintile has nearly four times the rate of HIUs compared to the least deprived. Similarly, higher rates are observed among Black, Mixed, and Other ethnic groups. HIUs are present across all NWL population segments. Those with SMI and learning disabilities have the highest rates, while the LTC65− and LTC65+ groups have the largest numbers of HIU patients, with around 4,500 and 2,500 individuals respectively.


::: callout-tip
##### Patient Insights

High Intensity Users

-   Some people with dementia are frequently brought into services during crises (e.g. falls, infections, or carer burnout).
-   Some in the healthy population make repeated service contact due to unmanaged anxiety or lack of early intervention.
-   People with LTCs often feel that they are bounced between services due to poor coordination and unclear care pathways.
-   For people with SMI, high admissions are linked to missed medication reviews or relapses.
-   People with LD may repeatedly use 111 and A&E services when proactive care plans are missing.
-   Children with complex needs often become high-intensity users due to their safeguarding concerns and a lack of joined-up care between services.
:::

## Patient Insights

The following table summarises key cross-cutting themes that emerge across population groups and topics, highlighting where experiences overlap and where improvements could have system-wide benefits.

| Cross-cutting theme | Description / examples | 
|--------|------------------------------------------|
| Missed or delayed prevention | Undiagnosed conditions (e.g. hypertension, cancer, COPD); post-diagnosis drop-off; low uptake of screening and checks, especially among LD, dementia, and healthy population. |  |  |  |
| Emotional and psychological burden | Emotional strain from self-managing LTCs or caregiving (e.g. dementia); untreated anxiety; lack of emotional support for carers. | 
| Fragmented or uncoordinated care | Care gaps across services (e.g. LTCs, complex children, LD); crisis-driven use of services; lack of care plans; disjointed navigation. |  
| Stigma, fear, and avoidance | Avoidance of services due to stigma (e.g. SMI, LD); mistrust in maternity or screening; healthy population feel excluded from targeted health offers. |  
| Barriers to communication and navigation | Language barriers, unclear communication (e.g. complex families, LD); system navigation confusion; multiple contact points with unclear responsibilities. | 
| Trust and relational care matter | Higher engagement when care is relational or peer-led (e.g. SMI, LD); trust built through known teams, personalised contact, and local delivery. |  


These insights illustrate how residents particularly those in Core20Plus5 communities — experience the health and care system, often in ways that reflect missed opportunities, structural barriers, or fragmented support. Recurring issues such as care discontinuity, mistrust, emotional strain, and limited access to prevention point to areas where a more joined-up, person-centred approach could drive meaningful improvement.


## Understanding Borough 

Across the different boroughs, variations in demographics and socio-economic factors influence health behaviours and outcomes. Much of the difference between boroughs can be attributed to these demographic and socio-economic factors, which in turn drive the variation in health needs. The graphs below show population segment breakdowns compared to NWL, as well as the LTCs and risk behaviours which are significantly worse then the NWL average, helping to illustrate how needs differ across boroughs.

The inner boroughs—Westminster, Kensington and Chelsea, and Hammersmith and Fulham, tend to have a higher proportion of healthy residents compared to NWL overall. In contrast, the outer boroughs, Ealing, Brent, Harrow, and Hillingdon have a lower proportion of healthy residents.

Health outcomes may also be influenced by differences in access to services. Understanding variations in risk behaviours and health outcomes can help identify priorities for improving service provision.

**Westminster Insights**
Despite the higher rate of healthy population in Westminster, it also has higher rates of SMI, cancer and depression, compared to the NWL average. Westminster has the highest rates of SMI in NWL. More insights for Westminster and Kensington and Chelsea can be found in the borough [JSNA](https://www.jsna.info/).

**Ealing Insights**
Ealing has a similar breakdown of population segments to NWL, however it has a larger proportion of healthy children and children with LTCs. Ealing has the highest rates of physical inactivity, alcohol abuse and CHD in NWL.  More insights for Ealing can be found in the borough [JSNA](https://data.ealing.gov.uk/jsna/).

**Brent Insights**
Hypertension and obesity are risk factors for developing diabetes and chronic kidney disease and we see a highest prevalence of all of these LTCs, except obesity, in Brent. There is a higher undiagnosed prevalence of hypertension in Black and Asian ethnic groups and in the most deprived areas (as shown by the HTN inequalities needs assessment) and this likely contributes to patterns of CKD and diabetes in Brent. 

To tackle these inequalities and improve outcomes, the Brent Health Matters programme delivers outreach events, bespoke clinical and self-management support, information and signposting to a range of services. Community Champions are at the heart of the programme to provide culturally appropriate services, including services for diabetes and hypertension. Primary care and INT programmes also have a focus on hypertension levels and inequalities. More insights for Brent can be found in the borough [JSNA](https://data.brent.gov.uk/search?q=jsna&topic=jsna).


**Kensington and Chelsea Insights**
K&C has a greater proportion of over 65s with LTCs compared to NWL but a smaller proportion over 18-64 with LTCS. There are also a higher proportions on SMI and depression compared to NWL. There is a particularly higher prevalence in Core20 areas in North K&C (Inclusive Health, NeoHealth, West-Hill Health PCNs) and there is work ongoing to target this cohort in the frailty workstream.   COPD has been marked as a key issue for K&C and is currently part of the health inequalities monitoring alongside Asthma and Diabetes

More insights for Westminster and Kensington and Chelsea can be found in the borough [JSNA](https://www.jsna.info/).

**Hammersmith and Fulham Insights**
H&F reports the highest recorded prevalence of cancer, COPD and depression in NWL, although generally has a healthier population.  More insights for Hammersmith and Fulham can be found in the borough [JSNA](https://www.lbhf.gov.uk/health-and-care/public-health/joint-strategic-needs-assessment-jsna).

**Harrow Insights**
Harrow has high rates of LTCs mostly driven by the older population, this is particularly reflected in the high rates of osteoporosis. More insights for Harrow can be found in the borough [JSNA](https://www.harrow.gov.uk/health-leisure/harrow-joint-strategic-needs-assessment).

**Hounslow Insights**
The Hounslow population is similar to the NWL average, however, reports higher rates of diabetes, obesity, CHD and hypertension. More insights for Hounslow can be found in the borough [JSNA](https://stats.hounslow.gov.uk/).

**Hillingdon Insights**
Hillingdon has higher rates of smoking and lower rates of blood pressure checks and flu vaccination compared to NWL. It also has the greatest number of LTCs that are significantly higher than the the NWL average, including anxiety, asthma, dementia, epilepsy and obesity.  More insights for Hillingdon can be found in the borough [JSNA](https://www.hillingdon.gov.uk/article/2979/Joint-Strategic-Needs-Assessment).

## Conclusion

In North West London, there is a young and generally healthy population compared to England. However, there are populations that are less healthy compared to the national average: Asian and Black ethnicities and those over 65. Equally, NWL has significant variation in the health status of its population, with those in more deprived communities having a shorter healthy lifespan. Understanding what risks and outcomes contribute to healthy life expectancy and inequality will help shape the priorities of the health and care system going forward.

::::: columns
::: {.column width="30%" .padded-right}

The table shows some of the key areas for improvement across different population segments. These topics include risks and outcomes that are significantly worse than England, have high prevalence in the segment, or have a large degree of inequality.

Understanding the different areas of unmet need in each segment allows the ICB to focus on the biggest issues for each population, ultimately providing a better service and improving population health outcomes. In particular, understanding and addressing the needs of the healthy population enables the ICB to start focusing on moving from sickness to prevention, one of the main themes from the NHS 10-year plan.

#### Cross-cutting areas of unmet need
**Mental Health**
<br>
North West London has greater needs compared to England in several areas, most notably among people with severe mental health conditions. NWL has nearly 30% more people detained under the Mental Health Act per 100,000 population compared to England. While the prevalence of severe mental illness (SMI) in NWL is similar to England, the substantial increase in detentions suggests that support for these patients is lacking. Detention rates are particularly high among Black populations, males, and people aged 18–34, highlighting groups who may not be receiving appropriate care.

Mental health service use is higher among people with SMI, especially those aged 18–64 compared to those over 65. This may indicate that older adults are not receiving the mental health support they need or are being treated in other parts of the system. People with SMI place a significant burden across all services, with high rates of A&E attendances, outpatient appointments, and unplanned bed days. Many are referred to mental health services via A&E, with rates especially high among those aged 18–65, the Core20 population, and people of Black or Mixed ethnicity. Demand for mental health services is likely to increase further, as anxiety and depression are the second and third long-term conditions with the greatest absolute growth in prevalence. This trend is also reflected in mental health contact rates among children, which are higher than among healthy adults. This may indicate better access to services for children, but it could also suggest rising expectations and future demand as this population ages.

Patient insights also highlight stigma around mental health, which may lead to avoidance of services and poorer outcomes over time.

**Cardio Renal Metabolic Conditions**
<br>
The LTCs with the greatest impact in NWL are hypertension, diabetes, and obesity—conditions linked through the cardio-renal-metabolic pathway. Obesity is an upstream risk factor for both diabetes and hypertension, and all three are major risk factors for more debilitating long term conditions such as coronary heart disease (CHD) and heart failure.

Diabetes is the only condition with overall prevalence higher than the national average across all age groups. Among those over 65, the gap between NWL and national diabetes prevalence widens compared to the younger age group, and hypertension prevalence in NWL also exceeds the national average. Obesity has shown the largest absolute increase in prevalence and the third highest relative increase over the last three years. Furthermore, obesity prevalence is likely underestimated due to the QoF definition used in this report. Childhood obesity is also a concern, with Year 6 children in NWL showing higher obesity rates than the national average. Obesity rates are particularly high in the most deprived populations and among Black and Asian communities. This condition is likely a significant factor contributing to lower levels of overall health in these populations and a driver of inequality.

**Inequalities**
<br>
Inequalities in disease prevalence, risk behaviours, and service use are largely preventable or modifiable, especially those driven by socioeconomic factors which is often summarized by deprivation. The table below highlights areas of need showing the greatest variation by key distal or indirect risk factors. These inequalities should be considered throughout service design and commissioning, particularly when services impact these areas.

::: {.small-table}

|-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------	|------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------	|----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------	|----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------	|
| A&E attendances <br>Mental health admissions <br>SMI recorded prevalence <br>Alcohol abuse <br>COPD recorded prevalence 	| A&E attendances <br>Mental health admissions <br>SMI recorded prevalence <br>Alcohol abuse <br>Diabetes recorded prevalence 	| A&E attendances <br>Alcohol abuse <br>CHD recorded prevalence <br>Peripheral arterial disease recorded prevalence<br>Epilepsy 	| Osteoporosis recorded prevalence <br>Rheumatoid arthritis recorded prevalence <br>Mental health contacts <br>Anxiety recorded prevalence <br>Depression recorded prevalence 	|

There is also evidence of inequality of care by how much we are spending on different ethnic and deprivation groups; there is a higher spend in the White, Black and more deprived populations, suggesting they experience more severe and costly health care

The analysis highlights inequalities across most health outcomes, particularly in service use. It also shows that deprivation and ethnicity are common factors contributing to poorer health outcomes.Both characteristics interact with each other, for example a greater proportion of the black population lives in a deprived area compared to the White population. However, ethnicity and socioeconomic deprivation can also pose distinct challenges to health. Survey evidence reveals that a substantial proportion of patients—especially those from ethnic minority backgrounds—report experiencing discrimination from NHS providers. This leads to reduced engagement, avoidance of care, and mistrust, all of which are linked to worse outcomes. Black, Asian, and other minority groups consistently report negative experiences across the care pathway, such as feeling dismissed, encountering language barriers, and lacking culturally appropriate services [NHS RHO, 2025](https://www.nhsrho.org/wp-content/uploads/2025/03/TRUST-IN-PRIMARY-CARE-REPORT.pdf). Similarly, those in the most deprived populations face comparable challenges due to mistrust of public institutions, which often stems from systems that are not designed to meet their needs. [Kings Fund, 2024](https://www.kingsfund.org.uk/insight-and-analysis/long-reads/relationship-poverty-nhs-services)

Insights from NWL patients highlight recurring issues with access, including poor care coordination, limited communication, and lack of trust. Addressing these barriers should be a priority in all aspects of ICB planning.
